content: The Federal Employees Health Benefits (FEHB) Program offers private health insurance to federal employees, retirees, and their dependents, with over $40 billion in annual benefits. Approximately 8.2 million individuals are covered each year, with 85% of employees and 90% of retirees participating. Coverage options include individual, family, and self plus one plans starting in 2016. Coverage options in FEHB are voluntary, with 85% of federal employees and 90% of retirees participating. Eligible individuals can choose individual, family, or self plus one coverage in an approved health benefits plan. Plans are either fee-for-service (FFS) or health maintenance organizations (HMOs), with premiums shared between the federal government and the employee or retiree. Benefits and cost sharing vary among FEHB plans. Prior to the creation of FEHB in 1959, federal employees were unable to obtain health insurance through the federal government; instead, they could purchase plans from fee-for-service (FFS) or health maintenance organizations (HMOs) that covered basic services such as hospital and physician care with shared premiums. Cost sharing varies among FEHB plans, covering basic services like hospital and physician care with deductibles, co-payments, or coinsurance.
